frontmatter.title: Introduction: Perfect Subsets of the Real Line

children.value: Descriptive set theory nowadays is understood as the study of definable subsets of Polish Spaces. Many of its problems and techniques arose out of efforts to answer basic questions about the real numbers. A prominent example is the

children.value: Thus, to show that a set of reals has the same cardinality as

children.html: R\RR

children.value: , it suffices to show the set contains a perfect subset. The next theorem establishes that the Continuum Hypothesis holds for all closed subsets of

children.html: R\RR
R\RealR

children.value: , i.e. the set of all points for which any open neighborhood has
intersection with the given closed set.

children.value: The right hand side is a countable union of countable sets, hence countable.
We will later encounter an alternative (more constructive) proof that gives additional information about the complexity of the closed set

children.html: CCC

children.value: . For now we conclude with the fact we were aiming to prove in this lecture.

children.html: R\RealR

children.value: is either countable or of the cardinality of the continuum.
The results of this lecture give us a blueprint on how to verify the Continuum Hypothesis for a given family

children.html: F\mathcal{F}F
F\mathcal{F}F
F\mathcal{F}F

children.value: is either countable or has a perfect subset.
Which families of sets have the perfect set property?
